data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: Prior to the manipulation, the study includes measures of system justification and self-esteem. Exploratory analysis will consider these personality measures as covariates and potential moderators. Fein & Spencer (1997) found that derogation of outgroups serves to enhance self-esteem, therefore we may see greater derogation (and perhaps authenticity) for those low in self-esteem. If the sample responses are sufficiently detailed, prime responses may be submitted to LIWC for linguistic analysis and exploratory investigation of whether thematic frequency (e.g., of negative affect) correlates with greater reported authenticity at the end of the study.

sample.value: In the absence of prior effect sizes, we will target a sample for analysis of 159 (53/cell). This is sufficient to achieve .8 power to detect a medium size effect in an omnibus one-way ANOVA with three groups. Given that we are unsure of how many participants will fail key attention checks, we plan to oversample by 20% (159+32 = 191) to ensure that we have a full 159 cases for analysis.

analyses.value:
Analysis will be:
1) Simple one-way ANOVAs on the three PANAS subscales and the SCC/Authenticity scales.
2) Tests of mediation of any effect of condition on SCC/Authenticity by state affect. 

It is expected that if thinking of disliked outgroups boosts authenticity, that effect will be due in part to increased feelings of anger (but not fear or joviality).

outliers.value: Cases will be excluded if they fail critical attention checks during the study. Additionally, participants will be asked to recall the theme of their prompt during the study at the debriefing. If they incorrectly recall their prompt, their data will be excluded from analysis.

dependent.value:
The outcome variables are:
1) Self-Concept Clarity (Campbell et al., 1996)
2) The Authenticity Scale (Wood et al., 2008)

Additionally, a 20-item PANAS has been included after the manipulation as a manipulation check and a potential vehicle to test mediation by state affect. This measure includes the aggressiveness, fearfulness, and joviality subscales (Watson & Clark, 1999)

conditions.value: Participants will write about either an outgroup that makes them angry, an outgroup that makes them happy, or an outrgroup that is unfamiliar or unknown to them (control).

hypothesis.value: This study tests whether reminders of a disliked outgroup cause a subsequent increase in authenticity. Insofar as outgroups are disliked for violating personally held values and beliefs, we anticipate that this dislike will ironically increase confidence that one understands who they really are.

attributes.title: The Influence of Trait Anxiety on Phasic Threatening Semantics and Prosody: Evidence from Electroencephalography

q1.value: The Influence of Trait Anxiety on Phasic Threatening Semantics and Prosody: Evidence from Electroencephalography

q2.value: Simon Busch-Moreno, David Vinson, Jyrki Tuomainen

q3.value:
The present study aims to extend the research presented in our previous work (Busch-Moreno, Tuomainen, and Vinson, 2020). We based our hypotheses in the combined predictions of multistage models of emotional language (Kotz and Paulmann, 2011) and Anxiety (Bar-Haim et al., 2007), which predict different responses to threatening language stimuli at different time-windows during the processing of the speech signal. In our previous electroencephalography (EEG) research, we predicted that higher anxiety levels not only delay responses, but also elicit a larger positive component (event-related potential: ERP) at late processing stages; interpreted as an late positive complex (LPC). However, we observed either null, spurious or very weak evidence for effects arising at earlier time windows. 
With this in mind, we designed the present EEG experiment as a passive listening task, using very controlled threatening phrases. This might allow us to capture early stage effects. In short, participants have to listen to phrases formulated in the second person (e.g.: ‘you’re stupid’, ‘you’re calm’) that contained threatening semantics only, threatening prosody only, both types of threat (congruent), or no threat at all (neutral). Participants’ anxiety levels will be measured using a behavioural inhibition system (BIS) scale (Corr and Cooper, 2016), where higher scores are associated with trait anxiety (overactive BIS) and related cognitive processes such as worry and rumination. Given our extended version of the multistage models, anxiety should interact in different ways with different language properties depending on processing stage.

q4.value:
Therefore, we hypothesize that: 1) Only language type (category) should induce effects at pre-attentive early stages (20-180ms), given the slow-down of semantic threat recognition induced by the need to locate a lexical item as opposed to the saliency of prosody. 2) Anxiety mechanisms of over-attention to threat should induce effects at early-mid (mid1: 180-320ms) stages, given faster threat detection; prosody should prime at this stage. 3) Over-attention should also induce greater effects at mid-late (mid2: 320-520ms) stages for semantic stimuli, as these stages involve identification and integration of lexical content and faster recognition should involve faster and stronger emotional integration/categorization. 4) Anxiety mechanism of over-engagement with threat should induce a late stage (520-780ms) LPC for any type of threat, as worry or rumination should be elicited by threat irrespective of information type (i.e. semantic or prosody). In this way, congruent and neutral stimuli should provide a double-edge baseline, where predicted effects should be noticeable by comparing semantic-only and prosody-only stimuli. Specific predictions can be seen in Table 1 below.


Table 1. Predictions in terms of main effects and interactions
Time window	Main Effects	Interactions	ERP
Early (20-180ms)	Language type (Category)	---	P1/N1
Mid1 (180-320ms)	Anxiety (BIS)	Category x BIS	P2/N2
Mid2 (320-520ms)	Anxiety (BIS)	Category x BIS	P300/N400
Late (520-780ms)	Anxiety (BIS)	---	LPC


	Predictions for the first three stages are mainly derived from multistage models of emotional language (Kotz and Paulmann, 2011), previous research indicating possible relationships between specific ERPs and trait anxiety (e.g. Pell et al., 2015), and on our own prognosis given multistage models of anxiety (e.g. Bar-Haim et al., 2007; Corr and McNaughton, 2012). Predictions for the late stage are specifically based on our previous results (Busch-Moreno, Tuomainen and Vinson, 2020).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Participants
	Participants will be recruited using UCL’s SONA system, paid at a £7.50/hour rate, tested under GDPR protocols with UCL’s ethical approval. For consistency, participants will be kept in an age and gender range similar to our previous experiment (Busch-Moreno, Tuomainen, Vinson, 2020). Based on the high precision (credible interval width) obtained in this previous experiment we estimated that between 30 and 34 participants will be required for obtaining equivalent or higher precision (see Analysis below). 
Materials
	Stimuli consist of 200 phrases, all spoken in second person and ending in a noun or adjective Phrases were divided into four categories. 1) Neutral: neutral prosody and neutral semantics. 2) Prosody: threatening prosody and neutral semantics. 3) Semantic: Neutral prosody and neutral semantics. 4) Congruent: threatening prosody and threatening semantics. Phrase’s words were selected by frequency and valence/arousal. Frequency, as Zipf log scores, were extracted from SUBTLEX-UK (van Heuven et al., 2014), words < 2.9 and words >= 5 points were removed. Scores from ANEW (Warriner et al., 2013) norms were used to select threatening/neutral sentences, where words above 4 arousal points and below 5 valence points were considered threatening, and words below 5 arousal and above 4 valence points were considered neutral. Each phrase was recorded 4 times from a male English speaker (not professional) in an acoustically isolated chamber with a RODE NT1-A1 microphone. The speaker was instructed to speak in what he considered his own threatening or neutral voice for recording Prosody/Congruent and Semantic/Neutral sentences respectively. See Figure 1 for examples of recorded phrases. 

Sentences used in our previous experiment (Busch-Moreno, Tuomainen and Vinson, 2020) were rated in terms of arousal and valence (using ANEW’s manikin) and threat (8 points Likert scale). Prosodic and complexity measures were extracted from these sentences using Parselmouth (Jadoul et al., 2018) and EntroPy (Vallat, 2019). These included: median pitch, Hammarberg index, harmonicty, shimmer, jitter, center of spectral gravity, cepstral peak prominence, energy in air, power in air, spectral entropy and detrended fluctuation. Bayesian robust and LASSO models (see Annex), indicate that Median Pitch (increase) and Hammarberg index (decrease) are sufficient to predict increases in arousal and threat. The newly recorded 200 (50 per category) phrases will be selected based on predictions (posterior predictive checks) of ratings (valence, arousal and threat) made through the aforementioned models. The phrases showing the most consistent predicted scores will be selected. These will be rated in the same manner as previously used stimuli, we expect high similarity between predicted and actual ratings. This procedure is not only intended to standardize threat in terms of prosody (acoustic features) and comprehension (ratings), but also provides an experimentally and statistically strong item selection procedure.
Trait anxiety will be measured by a BIS scale from the Reinforcement Sensitivity Theory Personality Questionnaire (RST-PQ) (Corr and Cooper, 2016), which is a measure indicative of an overactive BIS with high construct validity and can be linked to worry and rumination (see: Busch-Moreno et al., 2020). 


Procedure
	Participants will complete a passive listening task (using random catch trials representing 10% of total trials). Participants will listen to the four categories of sentences (Neutral, Prosody, Semantic, Congruent), fully randomized, and EEG will be recorded with Biosemi 64 Ag/Cl electrodes cap (20/20 system) in an isolated chamber. Before this, participants will complete demographics and BIS questionnaires. Exclusion criteria will be: 1) not completion of the task; 2) not fulfilling pre-screening requirements (no hearing problems, no psychiatric or neurological problems, native English speakers, right handed); 3) extreme noise (irreparable by ICA or interpolation) in more than 40% of trials; 4) and less than 70% of correctly answered catch trials.

Before this, participants will complete demographics and BIS questionnaires. Exclusion criteria will be: 1) not completion of the task; 2) not fulfilling pre-screening requirements (no hearing problems, no psychiatric or neurological problems, native English speakers, right handed); 3) extreme noise (irreparable by ICA or interpolation) in more than 40% of trials; 4) and less than 70% of correctly answered catch trials.

q13.value:
We will extract mean amplitudes from four a priori time-windows, slightly modified from our previous experiment: Early (20-180ms), Mid1 (180-320ms), Mid2 (320-520ms), Late (520-780ms). After this, using PyMC3 (Salvatier et al., 2016), data will be fit into a robust regression, using the model described on Figure 2. The model corresponds to a hierarchical model that includes both varying intercepts and varying slopes. The first include subjects (30) and sentences (200) and the latter includes all 64 electrodes (i.e. 64 slopes). This responds to the rationale that participants and stimuli can induce random variation that mainly deviates estimations from central tendency (i.e. their varying intercepts are included to induce shrinkage); while electrodes are of theoretical interest and they can work as informative slopes thus resulting in 64 interdependent posterior distributions. Therefore, this will help in retrieving information equivalent to electrodes interacting with other variables but with each electrode representing a unique response, and at the same time retaining the pooled estimation of the main repressors and/or interactions (Gelman, 2006; McElreath, 2015). 

Therefore, this implies 384000 data-points, corresponding to 30 subjects, listening to 200 sentences (trials) and mean amplitude per-trial recorded from 64 electrodes.

q14.value: From data (mean amplitude) simulated to fit the model in Figure 2, 30 participants would provide the following precision: BIS main effect: 0.037 (ROPE length: 0.04). Congruent main effect: 1.81 (ROPE length: 2.10). Prosody main effect: 1.61 (ROPE length: 1.98). Semantic category: 1.84 (ROPE length: 2.26). BIS x Congruent: 0.051 (ROPE length: 0.06). BIS x Prosody: 0.051 (ROPE length: 0.06). BIS x Semantic: 0.056 (ROPE length: 0.06). These values indicate very good precision, as all HPDs’ lengths are smaller than respective ROPEs.

q15.value: Sample size was estimated in terms of precision, which is lowly sensitive to stopping rules, therefore we will focus on recruiting 30 participants or 2 to 4 more if necessary (i.e. if some previous participants need to be rejected).

question.value:
As this is a passive listening task, the only manipulated variable are stimuli:

Stimuli consist of 200 phrases, all spoken in second person and ending in a noun or adjective Phrases were divided into four categories. 1) Neutral: neutral prosody and neutral semantics. 2) Prosody: threatening prosody and neutral semantics. 3) Semantic: Neutral prosody and neutral semantics. 4) Congruent: threatening prosody and threatening semantics. Phrase’s words were selected by frequency and valence/arousal. Frequency, as Zipf log scores, were extracted from SUBTLEX-UK (van Heuven et al., 2014), words < 2.9 and words >= 5 points were removed. Scores from ANEW (Warriner et al., 2013) norms were used to select threatening/neutral sentences, where words above 4 arousal points and below 5 valence points were considered threatening, and words below 5 arousal and above 4 valence points were considered neutral. Each phrase was recorded 4 times from a male English speaker (not professional) in an acoustically isolated chamber with a RODE NT1-A1 microphone. The speaker was instructed to speak in what he considered his own threatening or neutral voice for recording Prosody/Congruent and Semantic/Neutral sentences respectively.

In addition, pseudo-random catch trials will placed during the task. These will simply request to recognise the final word listened in the previously presented phrase.

Preprocessing of EEG signals will follow an identical pipeline as our previous research (Busch-Moreno, Tuomainen and Vinson, 2020; see Annex). Following this, we will extract mean amplitudes from four a priori time-windows, slightly modified from our previous experiment: Early (20-180ms), Mid1 (180-320ms), Mid2 (320-520ms), Late (520-780ms). After this, using PyMC3 (Salvatier et al., 2016), data will be fit into a robust regression, using the model described on Figure 2. The model corresponds to a hierarchical model that includes both varying intercepts and varying slopes. The first include subjects (30) and sentences (200) and the latter includes all 64 electrodes (i.e. 64 slopes). This responds to the rationale that participants and stimuli can induce random variation that mainly deviates estimations from central tendency (i.e. their varying intercepts are included to induce shrinkage); while electrodes are of theoretical interest and they can work as informative slopes thus resulting in 64 interdependent posterior distributions. Therefore, this will help in retrieving information equivalent to electrodes interacting with other variables but with each electrode representing a unique response, and at the same time retaining the pooled estimation of the main repressors and/or interactions (Gelman, 2006; McElreath, 2015).

The Behavioural Inhibition System (BIS) score corresponds to the summ value of each score given by participants to each of the 23 items in the BIS-scale of the Reinforcement Sensitivity Theory Personality Questionnaire (RST-PQ) (Corr and Cooper, 2016).

Mean amplitudes from four a priori time-windows, slightly modified from our previous experiment: Early (20-180ms), Mid1 (180-320ms), Mid2 (320-520ms), Late (520-780ms) will be extracted.

Other scores and measures such as acoustic and valence/arousal measures are provided in the attached description of the procedures.

Analysis
	Preprocessing of EEG signals will follow an identical pipeline as our previous research (Busch-Moreno, Tuomainen and Vinson, 2020; see Annex). Following this, we will extract mean amplitudes from four a priori time-windows, slightly modified from our previous experiment: Early (20-180ms), Mid1 (180-320ms), Mid2 (320-520ms), Late (520-780ms). After this, using PyMC3 (Salvatier et al., 2016), data will be fit into a robust regression, using the model described on Figure 2. The model corresponds to a hierarchical model that includes both varying intercepts and varying slopes. The first include subjects (30) and sentences (200) and the latter includes all 64 electrodes (i.e. 64 slopes). This responds to the rationale that participants and stimuli can induce random variation that mainly deviates estimations from central tendency (i.e. their varying intercepts are included to induce shrinkage); while electrodes are of theoretical interest and they can work as informative slopes thus resulting in 64 interdependent posterior distributions. Therefore, this will help in retrieving information equivalent to electrodes interacting with other variables but with each electrode representing a unique response, and at the same time retaining the pooled estimation of the main repressors and/or interactions (Gelman, 2006; McElreath, 2015). 
If sampling, convergence or certainty problems arise, the following changes to the model are proposed. 1) Reparametrization, which would involve adapting priors of varying intercepts (e.g. horseshoe priors) to improve sampling and convergence. 2) The use of hyperpriors for varying, fixed or all priors; these would be implemented in case variance cannot be modeled as a single overarching variance, which could improve convergence and/or certainty. 3) Model reduction, which would imply dropping the interaction term, this could improve convergence and/or certainty. Model comparison would be implemented to ascertain whether any of these implemented procedures results in an improved model.  
Finally, to determine whether effects are truly present after sampling (2 chains, 1000 samples and 1000 tuning steps each using MCMC NUTS: see Salvatier et al., 2016), posterior distributions will be assessed using a region of practical equivalence (ROPE) (Kruschke, 2015), established as 2SDs (relaxed to 1SD if certainty is not good). Given this,  highest posterior density (HPD) intervals that are completely outside ROPEs are considered true effects, HPDs partially overlapping ROPEs (less than 80%) are considered spurious, and HPDs completely or almost completely overlapping with ROPEs are considered null effects.

q21.value: To determine whether effects are truly present after sampling (2 chains, 1000 samples and 1000 tuning steps each using MCMC NUTS: see Salvatier et al., 2016), posterior distributions will be assessed using a region of practical equivalence (ROPE) (Kruschke, 2015), established as 2SDs (relaxed to 1SD if certainty is not good). Given this,  highest posterior density (HPD) intervals that are completely outside ROPEs are considered true effects, HPDs partially overlapping ROPEs (less than 80%) are considered spurious, and HPDs completely or almost completely overlapping with ROPEs are considered null effects.

Procedure
	Participants will complete a passive listening task (using random catch trials representing 10% of total trials). Participants will listen to the four categories of sentences (Neutral, Prosody, Semantic, Congruent), fully randomized, and EEG will be recorded with Biosemi 64 Ag/Cl electrodes cap (20/20 system) in an isolated chamber. Before this, participants will complete demographics and BIS questionnaires. Exclusion criteria will be: 1) not completion of the task; 2) not fulfilling pre-screening requirements (no hearing problems, no psychiatric or neurological problems, native English speakers, right handed); 3) extreme noise (irreparable by ICA or interpolation) in more than 40% of trials; 4) and less than 70% of correctly answered catch trials.

q23.value: No imputation or similar procedure is required. Although, interpolation of noisy electrodes will be performed in an automated way. This is previous to obtaining the measure to be analysed (i.e. mean amplitude).

q24.value: Potential exploratory analyses will involve analysis of complexity measures of amplitude and/or frequency signals, which will be compared to complexity measures of acoustic signal; these analyses will follow equivalent or similar Bayesian procedures. Additional source localization analyses could also be considered.

registration_responses.q15: Sample size was estimated in terms of precision, which is lowly sensitive to stopping rules, therefore we will focus on recruiting 30 participants or 2 to 4 more if necessary (i.e. if some previous participants need to be rejected).
registration_responses.q21: To determine whether effects are truly present after sampling (2 chains, 1000 samples and 1000 tuning steps each using MCMC NUTS: see Salvatier et al., 2016), posterior distributions will be assessed using a region of practical equivalence (ROPE) (Kruschke, 2015), established as 2SDs (relaxed to 1SD if certainty is not good). Given this,  highest posterior density (HPD) intervals that are completely outside ROPEs are considered true effects, HPDs partially overlapping ROPEs (less than 80%) are considered spurious, and HPDs completely or almost completely overlapping with ROPEs are considered null effects.
registration_responses.q22:
Procedure
	Participants will complete a passive listening task (using random catch trials representing 10% of total trials). Participants will listen to the four categories of sentences (Neutral, Prosody, Semantic, Congruent), fully randomized, and EEG will be recorded with Biosemi 64 Ag/Cl electrodes cap (20/20 system) in an isolated chamber. Before this, participants will complete demographics and BIS questionnaires. Exclusion criteria will be: 1) not completion of the task; 2) not fulfilling pre-screening requirements (no hearing problems, no psychiatric or neurological problems, native English speakers, right handed); 3) extreme noise (irreparable by ICA or interpolation) in more than 40% of trials; 4) and less than 70% of correctly answered catch trials.
registration_responses.q23: No imputation or similar procedure is required. Although, interpolation of noisy electrodes will be performed in an automated way. This is previous to obtaining the measure to be analysed (i.e. mean amplitude).
registration_responses.q24: Potential exploratory analyses will involve analysis of complexity measures of amplitude and/or frequency signals, which will be compared to complexity measures of acoustic signal; these analyses will follow equivalent or similar Bayesian procedures. Additional source localization analyses could also be considered.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Participants
	Participants will be recruited using UCL’s SONA system, paid at a £7.50/hour rate, tested under GDPR protocols with UCL’s ethical approval. For consistency, participants will be kept in an age and gender range similar to our previous experiment (Busch-Moreno, Tuomainen, Vinson, 2020). Based on the high precision (credible interval width) obtained in this previous experiment we estimated that between 30 and 34 participants will be required for obtaining equivalent or higher precision (see Analysis below). 
Materials
	Stimuli consist of 200 phrases, all spoken in second person and ending in a noun or adjective Phrases were divided into four categories. 1) Neutral: neutral prosody and neutral semantics. 2) Prosody: threatening prosody and neutral semantics. 3) Semantic: Neutral prosody and neutral semantics. 4) Congruent: threatening prosody and threatening semantics. Phrase’s words were selected by frequency and valence/arousal. Frequency, as Zipf log scores, were extracted from SUBTLEX-UK (van Heuven et al., 2014), words < 2.9 and words >= 5 points were removed. Scores from ANEW (Warriner et al., 2013) norms were used to select threatening/neutral sentences, where words above 4 arousal points and below 5 valence points were considered threatening, and words below 5 arousal and above 4 valence points were considered neutral. Each phrase was recorded 4 times from a male English speaker (not professional) in an acoustically isolated chamber with a RODE NT1-A1 microphone. The speaker was instructed to speak in what he considered his own threatening or neutral voice for recording Prosody/Congruent and Semantic/Neutral sentences respectively. See Figure 1 for examples of recorded phrases. 

Sentences used in our previous experiment (Busch-Moreno, Tuomainen and Vinson, 2020) were rated in terms of arousal and valence (using ANEW’s manikin) and threat (8 points Likert scale). Prosodic and complexity measures were extracted from these sentences using Parselmouth (Jadoul et al., 2018) and EntroPy (Vallat, 2019). These included: median pitch, Hammarberg index, harmonicty, shimmer, jitter, center of spectral gravity, cepstral peak prominence, energy in air, power in air, spectral entropy and detrended fluctuation. Bayesian robust and LASSO models (see Annex), indicate that Median Pitch (increase) and Hammarberg index (decrease) are sufficient to predict increases in arousal and threat. The newly recorded 200 (50 per category) phrases will be selected based on predictions (posterior predictive checks) of ratings (valence, arousal and threat) made through the aforementioned models. The phrases showing the most consistent predicted scores will be selected. These will be rated in the same manner as previously used stimuli, we expect high similarity between predicted and actual ratings. This procedure is not only intended to standardize threat in terms of prosody (acoustic features) and comprehension (ratings), but also provides an experimentally and statistically strong item selection procedure.
Trait anxiety will be measured by a BIS scale from the Reinforcement Sensitivity Theory Personality Questionnaire (RST-PQ) (Corr and Cooper, 2016), which is a measure indicative of an overactive BIS with high construct validity and can be linked to worry and rumination (see: Busch-Moreno et al., 2020). 


Procedure
	Participants will complete a passive listening task (using random catch trials representing 10% of total trials). Participants will listen to the four categories of sentences (Neutral, Prosody, Semantic, Congruent), fully randomized, and EEG will be recorded with Biosemi 64 Ag/Cl electrodes cap (20/20 system) in an isolated chamber. Before this, participants will complete demographics and BIS questionnaires. Exclusion criteria will be: 1) not completion of the task; 2) not fulfilling pre-screening requirements (no hearing problems, no psychiatric or neurological problems, native English speakers, right handed); 3) extreme noise (irreparable by ICA or interpolation) in more than 40% of trials; 4) and less than 70% of correctly answered catch trials.

As this is a passive listening task, the only manipulated variable are stimuli:

Stimuli consist of 200 phrases, all spoken in second person and ending in a noun or adjective Phrases were divided into four categories. 1) Neutral: neutral prosody and neutral semantics. 2) Prosody: threatening prosody and neutral semantics. 3) Semantic: Neutral prosody and neutral semantics. 4) Congruent: threatening prosody and threatening semantics. Phrase’s words were selected by frequency and valence/arousal. Frequency, as Zipf log scores, were extracted from SUBTLEX-UK (van Heuven et al., 2014), words < 2.9 and words >= 5 points were removed. Each phrase was recorded 4 times from a male English speaker (not professional) in an acoustically isolated chamber with a RODE NT1-A1 microphone. The speaker was instructed to speak in what he considered his own threatening or neutral voice for recording Prosody/Congruent and Semantic/Neutral sentences respectively.

In addition, pseudo-random catch trials will placed during the task. These will simply request to recognise the final word listened in the previously presented phrase.
registration_responses.q17.question: Preprocessing of EEG signals will follow an identical pipeline as our previous research (Busch-Moreno, Tuomainen and Vinson, 2020; see Annex). Following this, we will extract mean amplitudes from four a priori time-windows, slightly modified from our previous experiment: Early (20-180ms), Mid1 (180-320ms), Mid2 (320-520ms), Late (520-780ms). After this, using PyMC3 (Salvatier et al., 2016), data will be fit into a robust regression, using the model described on Figure 2. The model corresponds to a hierarchical model that includes both varying intercepts and varying slopes. The first include subjects (30) and sentences (200) and the latter includes all 64 electrodes (i.e. 64 slopes). This responds to the rationale that participants and stimuli can induce random variation that mainly deviates estimations from central tendency (i.e. their varying intercepts are included to induce shrinkage); while electrodes are of theoretical interest and they can work as informative slopes thus resulting in 64 interdependent posterior distributions. Therefore, this will help in retrieving information equivalent to electrodes interacting with other variables but with each electrode representing a unique response, and at the same time retaining the pooled estimation of the main repressors and/or interactions (Gelman, 2006; McElreath, 2015).
registration_responses.q18.question:
The Behavioural Inhibition System (BIS) score corresponds to the summ value of each score given by participants to each of the 23 items in the BIS-scale of the Reinforcement Sensitivity Theory Personality Questionnaire (RST-PQ) (Corr and Cooper, 2016).

Mean amplitudes from four a priori time-windows, slightly modified from our previous experiment: Early (20-180ms), Mid1 (180-320ms), Mid2 (320-520ms), Late (520-780ms) will be extracted.

Other scores and measures such as acoustic and valence/arousal measures are provided in the attached description of the procedures.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Analysis
	Preprocessing of EEG signals will follow an identical pipeline as our previous research (Busch-Moreno, Tuomainen and Vinson, 2020; see Annex). Following this, we will extract mean amplitudes from four a priori time-windows, slightly modified from our previous experiment: Early (20-180ms), Mid1 (180-320ms), Mid2 (320-520ms), Late (520-780ms). After this, using PyMC3 (Salvatier et al., 2016), data will be fit into a robust regression, using the model described on Figure 2. The model corresponds to a hierarchical model that includes both varying intercepts and varying slopes. The first include subjects (30) and sentences (200) and the latter includes all 64 electrodes (i.e. 64 slopes). This responds to the rationale that participants and stimuli can induce random variation that mainly deviates estimations from central tendency (i.e. their varying intercepts are included to induce shrinkage); while electrodes are of theoretical interest and they can work as informative slopes thus resulting in 64 interdependent posterior distributions. Therefore, this will help in retrieving information equivalent to electrodes interacting with other variables but with each electrode representing a unique response, and at the same time retaining the pooled estimation of the main repressors and/or interactions (Gelman, 2006; McElreath, 2015). 
If sampling, convergence or certainty problems arise, the following changes to the model are proposed. 1) Reparametrization, which would involve adapting priors of varying intercepts (e.g. horseshoe priors) to improve sampling and convergence. 2) The use of hyperpriors for varying, fixed or all priors; these would be implemented in case variance cannot be modeled as a single overarching variance, which could improve convergence and/or certainty. 3) Model reduction, which would imply dropping the interaction term, this could improve convergence and/or certainty. Model comparison would be implemented to ascertain whether any of these implemented procedures results in an improved model.  
Finally, to determine whether effects are truly present after sampling (2 chains, 1000 samples and 1000 tuning steps each using MCMC NUTS: see Salvatier et al., 2016), posterior distributions will be assessed using a region of practical equivalence (ROPE) (Kruschke, 2015), established as 2SDs (relaxed to 1SD if certainty is not good). Given this,  highest posterior density (HPD) intervals that are completely outside ROPEs are considered true effects, HPDs partially overlapping ROPEs (less than 80%) are considered spurious, and HPDs completely or almost completely overlapping with ROPEs are considered null effects.

attributes.title: Eye movements during unequal attention splitting in a multiple object tracking task: Experiment 1
attributes.description: Attention allocation is a cognitive task that is highly used in our everyday lives. This experiment investigates our ability to unequally allocate our attention in a multiple object tracking task (MOT) that does not require identity-location bindings to be formed. This experiment monitors and records the eye movements of participants with the use of an eye tracker, to investigate whether goal-driven unequal attention allocation is mediated by equivalent eye movement patterns.

q1.value: Eye movements during unequal attention splitting in a multiple object tracking task: Experiment 1

q2.value: Veronika Hadjipanayi, Chris Kent, Casimir J.H. Ludwig

q3.value: Tracking multiple visual objects is a cognitive ability that is often required in both animal and human contexts. This ability has been extensively studied in an experimental setting using multiple object tracking (MOT) tasks. Evidence has been found for top-down strategic unequal attention allocation. This indicates that observers can indeed consciously decide to allocate their attention unequally based on the instructions and demands of a task. However, it could have been the case that these findings are a result of identity-location binding and not of unequal attention allocation. Identity-location binding problem refers to situations where an individual associates the particular identity of an object with its location. In order to control for this possibility, and further investigate unequal attention allocation, the present experiment will use a modified MOT task that will not require participants to form identity-location bindings. Eye movements of participants will also be recorded during the MOT task, to offer a further insight into how participants allocate their allocation and track moving targets, by monitoring where and for how long participants look.

q4.value:
H1(directional): Tracking accuracy will be higher (i.e. less error) in high probability areas than in low probability areas of the screen.

H2(directional): Prolonged eye gaze (i.e. fixations and smooth pursuits) will be noted in high probability areas versus low probability areas of the screen, indexed as higher duration, in milliseconds, of eye gaze (i.e. fixations and smooth pursuits) spent on each of the two screen parts.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study will involve a repeated measures design with priority of screen areas as the within-subject factor with three levels (high: 70, middle: 50, low: 30). One out of the two combinations of priority will be presented at the beginning of a given trial: 1) 70-30; 2) 50-50.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will recruited from the University of Bristol and surrounding areas via the School of Psychological Science Experimental Hours Scheme, word of mouth, and electronic adverts.
Participants must have normal or  corrected-to-normal vision and be less than 35 years old.

Participant recruitment is expected to last approximately 2 months, depending on participants availability.

q13.value: Our target sample is a minimum of 33 participants.

q14.value: Data from Crowe et al. (2019) Experiment 1 indicated an effect size of d = 0.65 for the difference in error of tracking means between the 25% and 75% likelihood conditions of being probed on direction of travel estimates. Based on these data, we require a minimum sample size of 33 participants (two-tailed) to achieve 95% power of detecting a similar effect size at an alpha of 0.05.

question.value: Priority of screen areas will be manipulated in a within-subjects design with three levels: high (70%), equal (50%) and low (30%). On a given trial, the combined values total 100 so numbers will be presented in three different combinations: 70-30 (i.e. 70 in the top and 30 in the bottom part of the screen), 50-50 or 30-70 (i.e. 30 in the top and 70 in the bottom part of the screen). These numbers represent the likelihood of the 'questioned' target appearing in the top or in the bottom part of the screen respectively.

Three dependent variables are measured:  tracking error, time spent on each screen part and deviation from the centre. Tracking error is indexed by the relative difference (in pixels) between participants’ estimated direction of heading and the actual direction of heading of the target. Higher values represent greater discrepancy between estimated and actual target heading and therefore represent greater error (where zero is perfect accuracy) so less tracking accuracy. Overall time spent on each of the screen part is indexed as the duration, in milliseconds, of eye gaze (i.e. fixations and smooth pursuits) spent on each of the two screen parts. Deviation from the centre is indexed as the vertical distance above (i.e. + sign) or below (i.e. – sign) the centre of the screen.

Linear Mixed Effects models (LMEs) will be used to analyse the data using the lme4 package for the R computing environment (R Development Core Team, 2014).

Following Crowe et al. (2019), a model analysis will be conducted to estimate the guessing rate and precision of tracking. A Von Mises distribution will be used for the tracking error and a circular-uniform distribution for the guessing distribution. The mean of standard deviation of the Von Mises distribution will be interpreted as the precision of tracked items, and the proportion of the circular-uniform distribution will be interpreted as the guessing rate.

q22.value: All experimental trials will be included in the analysis of all participants. Participants’ blinks in each trial will be excluded from further analysis.

q25.value:
Crowe, E. M., Howard, C. J., Attwood, A. S., & Kent, C. (2019). Goal-directed unequal 
attention allocation during multiple object tracking. Attention, Perception, & Psychophysics, 1-15.

attributes.title: Science beliefs, political ideology, and cognitive sophistication
attributes.description: Various mechanisms have been proposed to explain why individuals hold pro- or anti-science beliefs. Some models focus on the role of political ideology and motivated reasoning, arguing that greater cognitive sophistication enables individuals to interpret evidence in an identity-consistent manner. Other models focus on the roles of basic science knowledge and cognitive sophistication, arguing that more general science knowledge and greater cognitive sophistication facilitate pro-science beliefs. To test these competing accounts, we identified a large range of controversial issues that are ostensibly subject to ideological disagreement and examined the relative roles of political ideology, science knowledge, and cognitive sophistication. Our results, which are consistent across two different nationally representative samples of Americans (N = 1,709), indicate that a combination of basic science knowledge and cognitive sophistication contribute more to science beliefs about various topics than political ideology. Furthermore, we found limited evidence for identity-protective cognition (i.e., motivated reasoning). By investigating a broad array of science-related beliefs, our results adjudicate between four accounts of science attitudes and suggest that educators and policymakers should focus on increasing basic science literacy and critical thinking instead of focusing on the ideological factors that divide people.

summary.value:
A formatted word document of this preregistration is attached. 

The purpose of this study is to examine the extent to which people believe specific science topics and science facts (used in Studies 1 and 2) are politically divisive.
Information from this study will be used to evaluate and reorganize the results that are already reported in Studies 1 and 2. 

The original goal of this set of studies was to generate a fairly comprehensive set of scientific issues in order to test several theoretically derived predictions. These predictions concerns tests of motivated reasoning and the politicization of science beliefs, but they also concern the extent to which science knowledge is a predictor of a range of science beliefs. Thus, political disagreement is not relevant to every analysis in this set of studies. Therefore, we outline a set of procedures below determining how we will use the information obtained in this test. 

Participants
Participants (N = 200) are recruited from Lucid.

Method
Subjects are asked to consider 17 statements (e.g. "Global warming is at least partly caused by human activity and is a serious problem for the environment.")
and 12 science facts (e.g. "Electrons are smaller than atoms") and are asked:
"Do you think this is something that Democrats and Republicans are likely to disagree on?" Options are Yes or No.
All items are presented in randomized order.

Analysis
All items are analyzed individually:
The percentage of 'Yes' responses (e.g. indicating the belief that Democrats and Republicans would disagree) for each statement is calculated.
The percentage of 'Yes' responses for each science fact is also calculated.
Analysis script is attached.
Data will be interpreted in percentages, only. 
There is no exclusion criteria; missing data will be treated as follows: If a subject is missing data on an item, they will be excluded from that calculation but will be included in other analyses for which they have data.

Results
Science statements with 50% agreement or greater will be considered politically divisive for the purposes of this study.
We choose a 50% cutoff so that we can include a range of items that are politically divisive to a greater and lesser extent. That is, we don't want a set of only highly divisive items, but we want to identify meaningful disagreement. However, we do want to remove items for which there is unlikely to be any level of political disagreement (i.e. where agreement is less than 50%) from relevant analyses.

No non-divisive items will be removed from analyses comparing the predictive power of ideology and deficit models. This includes tests of Fisher's r-to-z, and regression analyses using the composite liberal and conservative pro-science scales. 

Non-divisive items will be identified in all analyses using individual items, but the analyses as currently reported will remain the same. This includes the individual items correlations and the tests of political X cognitive sophistication interactions for each individual item. 

The 12 science facts are included here for comparative purposes only; we will not change any analyses or calculations based on whether or not people think these items are divisive.

No non-divisive items will be removed from analyses comparing the predictive power of ideology and deficit models. This includes tests of Fisher's r-to-z, and regression analyses using the composite liberal and conservative pro-science scales. 

Non-divisive items will be identified in all analyses using individual items, but the analyses as currently reported will remain the same. This includes the individual items correlations and the tests of political X cognitive sophistication interactions for each individual item. 

The 12 science facts are included here for comparative purposes only; we will not change any analyses or calculations based on whether or not people think these items are divisive.

attributes.title: Do errors not matter? A replication attempt of Rigoni, Wilquin, Brass and, Burle, 2013

q1.value: Do errors not matter? A replication attempt of Rigoni, Wilquin, Brass and, Burle, 2013

q2.value: Charlotte Eben, Zhang Chen, Emiel Cracco, Marcel Brass, Joel Billieux, Frederick Verbruggen

q3.value: In the original study, the authors manipulated the participants’ belief in free will in a between-subject design and subsequently measured post-error slowing (i.e. slower responses after an incorrect trial compared with a correct trial) as a marker of cognitive control. They found less post-error slowing in the group with reduced belief in free will (anti-free-will group) compared with a control group in which beliefs in free will was not manipulated.

q4.value: As this is a direct replication of Rigoni, Wilquin, Brass, and Burle (2013), we hypothesize less post-error slowing in the anti-free-will group compared to the control group.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
All experimental code, analyses code, belief in free will manipulation and questionnaires are provided as supplementary materials to this project.

This will be a mixed design, with two within-subject factors and one between-subjects factor. The within-subject factors will be test moment (pre- and post-manipulation) and previous trial (correct and error). The between-subject factor will be group (anti-free-will, control).

Participants will complete a Simon task in which they have to react to the color of a circle (yellow or blue) using left and right response keys. Note, that the colors in the original study were green and red, but in order to avoid problems for color blind participants, we decided to use yellow and blue. The circle can either appear on the left or the right side of the screen, but the stimulus location is irrelevant for the response. Therefore, there will be trials in which the response key and the location of the stimulus match (congruent trials; i.e. right side on the screen–right response key, or left side on the screen–left response key), and trials on which the response key and location do not match (incongruent trials; i.e. right side on the screen–left response key or left side of the screen–right response key). The color and stimulus location will be pseudo-randomised within subjects (equal probability of all combinations; i.e. yellow left location, yellow right location, blue left location, blue right location). 

In accordance with the original code provided by the first author of the original study (31/10/2019), first a fixation cross will be presented for 500 ms, after which the stimulus will be presented. The stimulus remains on the screen until the participant’s response. After the response there will be no feedback and the next trial starts. We tested the Simon task procedure without feedback in a pilot study (N=40) and observed PES even without a feedback signal. These data will be made available as well.

The general procedure will start with welcoming the participant, asking for consent and demographic details such as age, gender and nationality, and explaining the general procedure. The experiment will consist of three main parts. 

In the pre-manipulation test moment participants will perform the Simon task. In total, they will complete a practice block with 16 trials and four experimental blocks with 96 trials each.

For the manipulation, participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups. Both groups will read passages from The Astonishing Hypothesis, by Francis Crick (1994). The anti-free-will group will read a text claiming that scientists now recognize that free will is an illusion, while control group read a passage that does not mention free will. In addition, we will tell participants that they have to be able to answer two questions about the text at the end of the experiment. This is to make sure that participants read the manipulation texts carefully.

After this, in the post-manipulation test moment, participants again perform four blocks of the Simon task with 96 trials each. When all blocks are completed, participants fill in the Free Will Inventory (FWI) and an impulsivity questionnaire (UPPS-P short). The FWI (see Supplementary Materials) consists of 15 Likert-type items (scores from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree)) with three subscales (Free Will, Determinism and Dualism/Anti-Reductionism). Note that in the original study the Free will and Determinism plus (FAD plus) was used. However, follow-up studies (including an online study) used the FWI for manipulation check, as the FWI might be more sensitive than the FAD (Genschow, Rigoni, & Brass, 2017).  The impulsivity questionnaire is an addition as this project will be part of a larger individual-differences project across studies. We will not use the UPPS-P data for this study. Please note that we decided to drop the PANAS (a questionnaire used to measure positive and negative affect) as an additional measurement as it was shown in the original study that reading the manipulation text did not influence the PANAS scores. Note, that we also decided to drop the pre FWI measurement. We will only have one test session and therefore only 30 minutes between the testmoments. We assume that the pre FWI testmoment would bias the outcome of the post FWI measurement.

q9.value: We will use a simple randomization. Participants will be randomly assigned to the control group and anti-free-will group.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Population and Recruitment: Participants will be recruited through prolific, a crowdsourcing online platform (https://www.prolific.co/).  Participants have to be at least 18 years old and need to be fluent in English.

Qualification requirements: Participants must be 18 years of age to participate and be able to speak English. We will only test students to keep the sample as similar as possible to the original study.

Payment and duration: Participants will be paid £6 per hour for agreeing to participate. Because this study will take approximately 30 minutes to complete, we will pay participants £ 3 for their work on the study.

q13.value: We set a minimum sample size of 100 participants per group and a maximal sample size of 200 participants per group (so 400 participants in total).

q14.value:
To determine our sample size, we will use sequential Bayesian hypothesis testing (see Data Analysis section for further details) by increasing the sample until a decisive Bayes Factor (BF) larger than 10 (or < 1/10) is obtained (Schönbrodt, Wagenmakers, Zehetleitner, & Perugini, 2017).We will calculate the BF based on the ANOVA (frequentist and Bayesian equivalent) with test moment as within subject factor and group as between subject factor. The difference score between pre- and post-error as calculated with the Dutilh et al. (2012) method (see below) will be the dependent variable here, as this measure is not contaminated by global fluctuations (unlike the traditional method used in the original study). 

The minimum sample size (200) is based on recommendations by Brysbaert (2019). More specifically, Brysbaert (2019) suggested that 100 participants per group is the minimum sample size for a standard two-way ANOVA (we are mainly interested in the effect of pre- and post-manipulation and the group on the size of post-error slowing as a difference score) with one repeated-measures factor, one between-groups factor, and with r = .90 (i.e. the correlation between the within-subject variables). If Bayes Factors are undecisive, we will gradually increase sample size in steps of 50 (25 per group). The maximum sample size of 400 (or 200 per group) is based on the suggestion that for a BF > 10 for the difference between groups there should be 190 participants per group (Brysbaert, 2019).

q15.value: The data collection procedure will give full control over exact sample size. We will stop data collection until our BF is larger than 10 (or < 1/10), with a maximum sample size of 200 participants per group.

question.value: We will manipulate beliefs in free will (see above).

We will measure the post-error slowing effect in two ways. First we will simply compare RTs after an error with the RTs after correct trials. This is how post-error slowing was quantified in the original study (and how it is traditionally done). However, this measure of post-error slowing might be confounded with global fluctuations in RT. Dutilh et al. (2012) offered a simple solution for this problem: post-error slowing can be measured by comparing post-error trials with the associated pre-error trials. For this, we will take sequences of four trials: correct, correct, error and correct. In this case, the trial before the error is a post-correct trial and the trial after the error is a post-error trial. We will calculate the difference score for each of these trial sequences and then calculate the mean difference score.

Moreover, we will measure the belief in free will score with the FWI questionnaire in the post-manipulation session.

In general, we will conduct all analyses as they were conducted in the original study. 

1. For the manipulation check, we run a t-test for independent samples on the FWI subscale scores to compare the score between the groups (anti-free will, control).

2. We will submit the mean correct RTs and the mean error rate to a mixed ANOVA (frequentist and Bayesian equivalent) with congruency (congruent, incongruent) as within-subjects factor and group (anti-free will, control) as between-subjects factor within the pre-manipulation phase to check whether the groups already differed from each other in the pre-manipulation phase.


3. RTs, and error rates will be submitted to ANOVA (frequentist and Bayesian equivalent) with test moment (pre- vs. post-manipulation) and previous trial (correct or error) as within-subjects factors, and group as between-subjects factors. In case of a significant interaction, we will use paired t-tests (frequentist and Bayesian equivalent) to measure the size of post-error slowing across sessions within each group.

4. For the Dutilh et al. method, we will use the Dutilh et al. difference score and submit it to an ANOVA with test moment (pre- vs. post-manipulation) as within subject factor and group (anti-free will vs. control) as between subject factor. In case of a significant interaction, we will use paired t-tests (frequentist and Bayesian equivalent) to measure the size of post-error slowing across sessions within each group.

q20.value:
As noted above, we will measure the size of post-error slowing in two distinct ways. First, we will transform RT into a difference score between trials after an error and trials after a correct trial. In the original study this is referred to the post-error slowing effect.
Second, we measure the PES as suggested by Dutilh et al. (2012), by using sequences of four trials: correct, correct, error and correct. Here we calculate the difference between the correct trial before and the correct trial after the error. Like this we calculate the difference between a post-correct/pre-error trial and the corresponding post-error trial.

q21.value: We will report p-values. Significance will be determined at an alpha level of .05. An ANOVA (frequentist and Bayesian equivalent) and frequentist and Bayesian two-tailed t-tests will be used. We will report the two-tailed Bayes Factor BF10 (calculated with the Bayes Factor package version 0.9.12-2 in R) which quantifies the evidence for the alternative hypothesis against the null hypothesis. Given the fact, that the original sample size is relatively small, we assume the effect size from the original study may not be a good estimate for the population effect size. Therefore, we decided to use the default prior widths as defined by the Bayes Factor package in R. For Bayesian t-tests the Cauchy prior width is 0.707.

q22.value: Data exclusion is based on the original study as following: Concerning the Simon task, reaction times (RTs) faster than 100 ms and later than 1 s will not be considered in the analysis. Moreover, missing single trials (due to online data collection) and the following trial will be excluded as we cannot determine for the missing trials whether they were correct or not. Data from participants with very low accuracy across congruent and incongruent trials in the baseline Simon task (i.e. more than 2.5 standard deviations (SDs) lower than entire sample average) will not be analyzed and replaced.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete the UPPS-P, we will still include them for the RT analyses. However, we need the FWI scores to include participants in the analyses. Moreover, it is possible that single trials will not be recorded, as we are testing online. These trials will be replaced with NA. Note, that we will exclude all participants with more than 5% missing trials and replace them by testing new participants. Given the fact that we need errors for the analysis of PES, we exclude participants that have an accuracy of 100% or an accuracy of 100% in some cells of the ANOVA. To check whether participants actually read the manipulation text, we include two yes/no-questions. If participants fail to answer these questions (see supplementary material) and took less than 45 seconds to read the text, we will exclude these participants. In order to meet our aimed sample size and Bayes Factors, all excluded participants will be replaced.

q24.value: One factor that was included in the original study but not taken into account was congruency. However, the likelihood to commit an error is higher in incongruent trials than in congruent trials. Due to this, the probability of a congruent trial might be marginally higher after an error than after a correct trial (due to the fact that congruent and incongruent trials occur equally often in a block). To test the idea that the post-error slowing is modulated by congruency, we will perform additional analyses with congruency as a third within-subject factor

attributes.title: Creating sustainable diets: knowledge versus nudges
attributes.description: This study aims to investigate two methods of promoting sustainable diets. One method involves eco-labeling and the other involves utilising social norms to nudge people towards sustainable choices. The primary research aim is to determine the effects of these two methods on food choice and the secondary research aim is to investigate how participants' motivation to live sustainably impacts these effects. The study has three conditions, one for each method and one control condition. Participants will be presented different variations of a food menu depending on their condition. We will measure the food choice frequency and participants' motivation to live sustianably.

attributes.title: The novel 2019 coronavirus (nCoV) infection in humans: A Systematic Review Protocol
attributes.description: This Systematic Review research project associates to an international task force to address the ongoing outbreak

q1.value: The novel 2019 coronavirus (nCoV) infection in humans: A Systematic Review Protocol

q2.value: Israel Junior Borges do Nascimento, Paula Souza Lage, Maria Bjorklund, Umesh Jayarajah, Meisam Abdar Esfahani, Ana Jeroncic, Arinjay Banerjee, Hebatullah Mohamed Ahmed Abdulazeem, Mohammad Altujjar, Nicola L Bragazzi, Haijiang Dai

q3.value: Coronaviruses are enveloped, positive single-stranded RNA viruses that infect both humans and other mammals. In December 2019, a novel coronavirus strain was isolated and name as “2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV)”, and were associated to a wide range of symptoms from a mild cough to pneumonia. Furthermore, no systematic analysis of published literature about the human infection caused by the 2019-nCoV could be identified. The Grading of Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE) approach describes specific conditions in which strong clinical recommendations can be made based upon low quality evidence as case reports and observational studies. Because of the severity of new coronavirus infections as well as its economic and social impact, a systematic review of published studies related these infections is of upmost relevance.

q4.value: Is the current body of literature summarizing all available information associated to 2019 novel coronavirus infections?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: The blinding will be used during screening, data extraction and risk of bias assessment.

question.value:
In order to identify studies related to the 2019 novel coronavirus infection, we will conduct a sensitive literature search using the following databases: PubMed/MEDLINE; the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL); EMBASE; LILACS (Latin American and Caribbean Health Science Information); and Scopus.

Additionally, we will search for reference list of all eligible studies.

No limits will be placed on the publication type or language.

All studies published from January 1, 2019 to February 19, 2020 will be analyzed.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: All data will be collected by a information specialist (Cochrane Sweden) who will initially process and check for duplicates. The study authors, a posteriori, will analyze sensible data from obtained and included studies for data extraction, quality assessment and quali-quantitative synthesis.

The primary outcomes in patients infected with the 2019 coronavirus will be: all-cause mortality rate, length of hospitalization, days in the ICU, days in the respiratory life support, and duration from illness onset to first admission. Secondary outcomes measures will comprise treatment given, other prognosis measures, complications, comorbid conditions, demographic and socioeconomic characteristics, any laboratory variables, any radiological variable, and any physiologic variable. We will process data from baseline and follow-up for suitable studies. If a study reported multiple follow-ups throughout the study duration, the most recent data was included (unless a relevant clinical parameter was contrasting). For studies evaluating economic, international recommendations, and social impact of the outbreak, a qualitative and descriptive analysis will be performed.
None to declare
None to declare
We plan to analyze all obtained data using descriptive synthesis.

q22.value: Studies in which not describe any analysis of the ongoing coronavirus infection will be excluded.

q23.value: We will contact studies authors for more information
